en.header: True or false? When you discuss with your client, it is better to use very specific and erudite vocabulary related to your expertise and the topic at hand.
en.klf: Give your client jargon-free advice, or they will likely be lost or confused. Obviously, they want you to know what you are talking about, but they don't need a scholarly lecture: they need clear and concrete advice to which they can easily relate.
en.tips: Actually, as a consultant, you will have to adapt to your client's language! You will have to learn the buzzwords or acronyms that are specific to the client you will be working with to be on the same wavelength.

fr.header: Vrai ou faux? Lorsque vous discutez avec votre client, il est préférable d’utiliser un vocabulaire très spécifique et érudit en rapport avec votre expertise et le sujet à traiter.
fr.klf: Donnez à vos clients des conseils sans jargon, sinon ils seront probablement perdus ou confus. De toute évidence, ils veulent que vous sachiez de quoi vous parlez, mais ils n'ont pas besoin d'une conférence savante: ils ont besoin de conseils clairs et concrets auxquels ils peuvent facilement s'identifier.
fr.tips: En fait, en tant que consultant, vous devrez vous adapter à la langue de votre client! Vous devrez apprendre les mots à la mode ou les acronymes spécifiques au client avec lequel vous allez travailler pour être sur la même longueur d’onde.

de.header: True or false? When you discuss with your client, it is better to use very specific and erudite vocabulary related to your expertise and the topic at hand.
de.klf: Give your client jargon-free advice, or they will likely be lost or confused. Obviously, they want you to know what you are talking about, but they don't need a scholarly lecture: they need clear and concrete advice to which they can easily relate.
de.tips: Actually, as a consultant, you will have to adapt to your client's language! You will have to learn the buzzwords or acronyms that are specific to the client you will be working with to be on the same wavelength.
